For all medication-round fills, MEPSDRUGID is an IPUMS-generated identifier that can be used to link drugs across rounds. AHRQ describes the original variable used to construct MEPSDRUGID as the "prescribed medicine drug-level ID." That is, MEPSDRUGID will have the same value for a given person across rounds for the same medication. This contrasts to MEPSLINKIDF that will have a new value in each round for the same medication. MEPSDRUGID is available beginning in 2009; from 1996 to 2008 RXNDC can be used to link drugs across rounds in most cases. Users should keep in mind that in some cases, RXNDC is not a perfect replacement for MEPSDRUGID because a respondent may have reported a slightly different drug name (the basis for assigning MEPSDRUGID) that was assigned the same drug fill information from the pharmacy (the basis for assigning RXNDC). Starting in 2008, drug fills with the same MEPSLINKIDF value may have different RXNDC values due to different manufacturers.
Construction of MEPSDRUGID MEPSDRUGID uniquely identifies prescribed medicines across MEPS panels. For 2009-2017, MEPSDRUGID is created by combining PANELF and DRUGID (DRUGID = DUPERSIDF + unique drug identifier). IPUMS MEPS staff create MESPDRUGID to provide a single, universal linking key for a persons prescribed medicines across MEPS panels.
Beginning in 2018, AHRQ modified the identifiers DUIDF and DUPERSIDF (which combines DUIDF with PIDF) on the original MEPS data files to append information about PANELF to the first two columns. That change makes DRUGID the same as MEPSDRUGID for 2018 forward.MEPSDRUGID is on the medication-round fill record (see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr: CodesMEPSDRUGID is a 13-character string variable.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: RXRECID
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, RXRECID is an AHRQ-generated identifier that uniquely identifies medication-round fill records. From 1996-2017, RXRECID begins with DUPERSIDF and uniquely identifies medication-round fill records within a panel. To uniquely identify records across all MEPS panels, please see MEPSRXRECID. Beginning in 2018, RXRECID uniquely identifies records across panels due to changes in the construction of DUPERSIDF to add PANELF to the first two digits of the DUPERSIDF identifier.
RXRECID is on the medication-round fill record (see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr: CodesFrom 1996-2017, RXRECID is a 15-character string variable. Beginning in 2018, RXRECID is a 19-character string variable.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: MEPSRXRECID
var.txt:
MEPSRXRECID uniquely identifies medication-round fill records across MEPS panels. MEPSRXRECID is created for 1996-2017 by combining PANELF, RXRECID, and a 2-digit event type number ("03" for prescribed medicines, "02" for other medical expenses, and "01" for all other event types).
Beginning in 2018, AHRQ modified the identifiers DUIDF and DUPERSIDF (which combines DUIDF with PIDF) on the original MEPS data files to append information about PANELF to the first two columns. AHRQ also added a 2-digit event type number beginning in 2018. MEPSRXRECID is the same as RXRECID for 2018 forward.
MEPSRXRECID is on the medication-round fill record (see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr: CodesMEPSRXRECID is a 23-character string variable.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: LINKIDF
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, LINKIDF is an AHRQ-generated identifier that uniquely identifies medication-round records. LINKIDF is created by combining DUPERSIDF with a numeric value that is the same for each fill of a medication within a given round. LINKIDF differs for the same medication across rounds (see MEPSDRUGID for a unique drug identifier across rounds). From 1996-2017, LINKIDF uniquely identifies medication-round records within a panel. To uniquely identify records across all MEPS panels, please see MEPSLINKIDF. Beginning in 2018, LINKIDF uniquely identifies medication-round records across panels due to changes in the construction of DUPERSIDF to add PANELF to the first two digits of the DUPERSIDF identifier and the addition of a 2-digit event type number.
Event-Medication-Round Record Linking The event, medication-round, and medication-round fill records can be joined together by using the event-medication-round link records. LINKIDF is on the medication-round fill record and is the same as LINKIDM on the medication-round record and LINKIDK on the event-medication-round link record. The event-medication-round link records (K rectype) and medication-round fill records (F rectype) can be linked to the medication-round records (M rectype) using LINKIDK, LINKIDF, and LINKIDM, respectively. However, due to changes in how LINKIDF is constructed over time, IPUMS MEPS recommends using MEPSLINKIDK, MEPSLINKIDM, and MEPSLINKIDF to join the event-medication-round link, medication-round, and medication-round fill records.
See our user note for more details on how to join the different record types and an overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr: CodesFrom 1996-2017, LINKIDF is a 12-character string variable. Beginning in 2018, LINKIDF is a 16-character string variable.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: MEPSLINKIDF
var.txt:
For all medication-round fill records, MEPSLINKIDF uniquely identifies medication-round records across MEPS panels. MEPSLINKIDF is created for 1996-2017 by combining PANELF, LINKIDF, and a 2-digit event type number ("03" for prescribed medicines, "02" for other medical expenses, and "01" for all other event types). IPUMS MEPS staff create MEPSLINKIDF to provide a single, universal linking key for linking across MEPS event and medication-round records.
Beginning in 2018, AHRQ modified the identifiers DUIDF and DUPERSIDF (which combines DUIDF with PIDF) on the original MEPS data files to append information about PANELF to the first two columns. AHRQ also added a 2-digit event type number beginning in 2018. MEPSLINKIDF is the same as LINKIDF for 2018 forward.
Event-Medication-Round Record Linking The event, medication-round, and medication-round fill records can be joined together by using the event-medication-round link records. MEPSLINKIDF is on the medication-round fill record and is the same as MEPSLINKIDK on the event-medication-round link record and MEPSLINKIDM on the medication-round record.Condition-Event Record Linking The medication-round fill and condition records can be joined together by using the condition-event link records. MEPSEVNTIDJ is on the condition-event link record and is the same as MEPSLINKIDF on the medication-round fill record.See our user note for more details on how to join the different record types and an overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr: CodesMEPSLINKIDF is a 16-character string variable.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: RXBEGMM
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills that are not diabetic equipment or supplies (see RXNAME), RXBEGMM reports the month in which the person began taking the medication. Respondents are only asked this question once, during the round in which they first report the new medicine. Subsequent rounds restate the previously reported value. During the initial asking of this question, if the year in which this medicine was first taken (reported in RXBEGYR) is not during or after the person's reference period, this question is not asked.
If respondents reported a date before their date of birth (or, if their date of birth is not available, a date after the reference period), this variable will be assigned a value of 98: Unknown Not Ascertained. If the medication is considered diabetic equipment or supplies, this variable is assigned a value of 0: "Not in Universe."
IPUMS MEPS reports the universe for each variable based on a thorough review of the original MEPS documentation. Investigating the data may reveal cases that do not meet the stated universe. Users are encouraged to validate universes for their analyses.
RXBEGMM is on the medication-round fill record (see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: RXBEGYR
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills that are not diabetic equipment or supplies (see RXNAME), RXBEGYR reports the year in which the person started taking the medicine. Respondents are only asked this question once, during the round in which they first report the new medicine. Subsequent rounds restate the previously reported value.
If respondents reported a date before their date of birth (or, if their date of birth is not available, a date after the reference period), this variable will be assigned a value of 9998: Unknown Not Ascertained. If the medication is considered diabetic equipment or supplies, this variable will be assigned a value of 0: "Not in Universe."
IPUMS MEPS reports the universe for each variable based on a thorough review of the original MEPS documentation. Investigating the data may reveal cases that do not meet the stated universe. Users are encouraged to validate universes for their analyses.
RXBEGYR is on the medication-round fill record (see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr: CodesRXBEGYR is a four-digit numeric variable.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: RXNAME
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, except those determined to be a confidentiality risk (see below), RXNAME reports the unedited pharmacy-provided name of the prescribed medicine. See also RXNDC and RXDRGNAM for additional information about prescribed medication-round fill attributes.
A drug can pose a confidentiality risk for several reasons. Examples include orphan drugs, drugs that are estimated to be used by fewer than 200,000 people, or drug names that provide identifying information about the pharmacy or respondent. An orphan drug is a drug that treats a rare disease or condition but has been discontinued because there is little or no economic incentive to continue development or production. See Rare Diseases at the FDA for more information about how these drugs are designated and the effort to financially support their development and production under the Orphan Drug Act. See the codes tab for more detailed information about how cases that pose a confidentiality risk are handled in the data.
IPUMS MEPS reports the universe for each variable based on a thorough review of the original MEPS documentation. Investigating the data may reveal cases that do not meet the stated universe. Users are encouraged to validate universes for their analyses.
RXNAME is on the prescribed medication-round fill record (or "medication-round fill record," see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr:
CodesRXNAME is a 50-character string variable.
In 1996-2006 samples, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk, RXNAME is assigned a value of 0: "Not in Universe." Users should note that in the original documentation, this value was -9: "Not Ascertained."
In 2015-onward samples, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be an orphan drug or a drug estimated to be used by fewer than 200,000 people, the most detailed Multum Lexicon therapeutic classification value available (see MULTC1) replaced RXNAME (pharmacy-reported medication name). The most detailed classification value available means that if a medication fill has a sub-sub-class value assigned, such as "SSRI antidepressants," this is the value used for RXNAME in the case that the drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk. If a medication fill has a sub-class value, such as "antidepressants," but no sub-sub-class value is assigned, then the sub-class value is the value used for RXNAME. If a medication fill has a class value, such as "psychotherapeutic agents," but no sub-class or sub-sub-class value is assigned, then the class value is the value used for RXNAME.
In 2015-onward samples, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk for reasons other than it being an orphan drug or a drug used by fewer than 200,000 people, RXNAME is assigned a value of 0: "Not in Universe." Users should note that in the original documentation for 2018-onward samples, this value was -15: "Cannot be Computed."
In 2007, 2009, and 2010 samples, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk, the original documentation suggests that the most detailed Multum Lexicon therapeutic classification value available replaced RXNAME, however, the data indicate that RXNAME is assigned a value of 0: "Not in Universe."
In 2008, 2011, and 2012 samples, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk, the original documentation suggests that the most detailed Multum Lexicon therapeutic classification value available replaced RXNAME, however, neither the Multum Lexicon therapeutic classification values nor values of 0: "Not in Universe" are present in the data for RXNAME.
In the 2013 sample, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk, the original documentation suggests that the most detailed Multum Lexicon therapeutic classification value available replaced RXNAME, and the data indicates that this is the case. Additionally, the data contains RXNAME values of 0: "Not in Universe" that are not identified in the original documentation.
In the 2014 sample, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk, RXNAME is assigned a value of 0: "Not in Universe," which is in line with both the original documentation and the data. However, some RXNAME values are assigned the most detailed Multum Lexicon therapeutic classification value, which is not identified in the original documentation.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: RXNDC
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, except for drugs determined to be a confidentiality risk (see below), RXNDC reports the National Drug Code (NDC) of the prescribed medicine. The NDC is provided during the pharmacy component of the MEPS survey. In cases where the NDC provided by the pharmacy is not valid, a secondary data source is used to impute a valid value for that prescribed medicine. See the comparability tab for more information about how these cases are handled over time. See also RXNAME and RXDRGNAM for additional information about prescribed medication-round fill attributes.
In most cases, each prescribed medicine is associated with one RXNDC value, however, each fill of a prescribed medicine can have a unique RXNDC value in cases where the medication's form, strength, manufacturer, or package size differ across fills. Thus, a prescribed medicine may have only been reported once in the household component but may be represented by multiple medication-round fills with unique RXNDC values in the data.
For 1996-2008 samples, RXNDC was used to link drugs across rounds. Beginning in 2009, DRUGID was introduced as the "prescribed medicine drug-level ID" and replaced RXNDC as the variable used to link drugs over time. See DRUGID for more information about linking drugs across MEPS rounds and see MEPSDRUGID for more information about linking drugs across MEPS panels.
A drug can pose a confidentiality risk for several reasons. Examples include orphan drugs, drugs that are estimated to be used by fewer than 200,000 people, or drug names that provide identifying information about the pharmacy or respondent. An orphan drug is a drug that treats a rare disease or condition but has been discontinued because there is little or no economic incentive to continue development or production. See Rare Diseases at the FDA for more information about how these drugs are designated and the effort to financially support their development and production under the Orphan Drug Act. See the codes tab for more detailed information about how cases that pose a confidentiality risk are handled in the data.
IPUMS MEPS reports the universe for each variable based on a thorough review of the original MEPS documentation. Investigating the data may reveal cases that do not meet the stated universe. Users are encouraged to validate universes for their analyses.
RXNDC is on the medication-round fill record (see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr:
CodesRXNDC is an 11-digit string variable. The first 5 digits of the NDC code report the manufacturer of the prescribed medicine. The next 4 digits of the NDC code report the form and strength of the prescription. The last 2 digits of the NDC code report the package size from which the prescription was dispensed.
In the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk, RXNDC is assigned a value of 0: "Not in Universe." Users should note that in the original documentation for 1996-2017 samples, this value was -9: "Not Ascertained," and in the original documentation for 2018-onward samples, this value was -15: "Cannot be Computed."
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: RXDAYSUP
var.labl: Days supplied of prescribed medicine, imputed
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, RXDAYSUP reports the number of days supplied for the medication fill.
IPUMS MEPS reports the universe for each variable based on a thorough review of the original MEPS documentation. Investigating the data may reveal cases that do not meet the stated universe. Users are encouraged to validate universes for their analyses.
RXDAYSUP is on the prescribed medication-round fill record (see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr:
CodesRXDAYSUP is a 4-digit numeric variable.
9995: Medication taken as needed 9996: Not in universe 9997: Unknown-refused 9998: Unknown-not ascertained 9999: Unknown-don't know
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: RXFEXPSRC
var.labl: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by source of payment
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, RXFEXPSRC is a set of expenditure variables indicating the amount paid for a prescribed medicine fill by source of payment. By adding RXFEXPSRC to your data cart, you are in effect adding twelve expenditure variables covering prescribed medications. These variables include:
RXFEXPSELF: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by self/family
RXFEXPMC: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by Medicare
RXFEXPMA: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by Medicaid
RXFEXPPRI: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by private insurance
RXFEXPVA: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by the Veteran's Administration
RXFEXPTRI: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by TRICARE
RXFEXPOF: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by other Federal sources
RXFEXPOL: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by other State and local sources
RXFEXPWC: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by Worker's Compensation
RXFEXPOPR: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by other private sources
RXFEXPOPU: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by other public sources
RXFEXPOS: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by other unclassified sources Related variables Expenditure variables related to other types of medical care by source of payment and by type of medical service are also available. Please refer to our user note on expenditures for more information about these variables.
var.codInstr: CodesRXFEXPSRC is a 1-digit numeric variable.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.labl: Amount paid for the prescribed medicine fill by self/family

Expenditure variables on the medication-round fill record do not incorporate any manufacturer discounts, coupons, or other rebates reported by pharmacies, because the manufacturer is paying itself. Free drugs, write-offs, and discounts from commercial pharmacies are not counted in expenditures, although these free drugs are on the medication-round fill record. Free drugs, write-offs, and discounts from safety net providers and government pharmacies are included in expenditures because they are paid with public sector funds.
RXFEXPSELF is on the medication-round fill record (see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
var.codInstr: CodesRXFEXPSELF is a 10-digit numeric variable with 2 implied decimal places. That is, values of 1234567899 should be interpreted as 12,345,678.99. The IPUMS command files automatically divide by 100, so no further adjustment is needed.

var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: RXDRGNAM
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, except diabetic equipment and supplies (see RXNAME) and drugs determined to be a confidentiality risk, RXDRGNAM reports the generic name most commonly used by prescribing physicians for the medication. The drug classification system used to assign RXDRGNAM has remained consistent over time, making it well-suited for trend analyses or pooling years or panels together. RXDRGNAM is assigned using the Multum Lexicon database (for more information about the Multum Lexicon database, see the following section). See also RXNAME and RXNDC for additional information about prescribed medication-round fill attributes.
A drug can pose a confidentiality risk for several reasons. Examples include orphan drugs, drugs that are estimated to be used by fewer than 200,00 people, or drug names that provide identifying information about the pharmacy or respondent. An orphan drug is a drug that treats a rare disease or condition but has been discontinued because there is little or no economic incentive to continue development or production. See Rare Diseases at the FDA for more information about how these drugs are designated and the effort to financially support their development and production under the Orphan Drug Act. See the codes tab for more detailed information about how these cases are handled in the data.
RXDRGNAM is on the prescribed medication-round fill record (or "medication-round fill record," see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
IPUMS MEPS reports the universe for each variable based on a thorough review of the original MEPS documentation. Investigating the data may reveal cases that do not meet the stated universe. Users are encouraged to validate universes for their analyses.
Multum Lexicon Variables
Cerner Multum, Inc. develops the Multum Lexicon database that MEPS uses to classify drugs reported by respondents in the MEPS-HC. Each drug is assigned a Multum drug name (RXDRGNAM), a pregnancy category (PREGCAT), and to one or more therapeutic class, sub-class, and sub-sub-class designations (see MULTC1 for more information about the Multum Lexicon variables).
Users of the Multum Lexicon variables should cite Multum Lexicon, AHRQ, and IPUMS MEPS as the data sources.
var.codInstr:
CodesRXDRGNAM is a 60-character string variable.
In 2014-onward samples, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk, the most detailed Multum Lexicon therapeutic classification value available (see MULTC1) replaced RXDRGNAM (Multum drug name). The most detailed classification value available means that if a medication fill has a sub-sub-class value assigned, such as SSRI antidepressants, this is the value used for RXDRGNAM in the case that the drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk. If a medication fill has a sub-class value, such as antidepressants, but no sub-sub-class value assigned, then the sub-class value is the value used for RXDRGNAM. If a medication fill has a class value, such as psychotherapeutic agents, but no sub-class or sub-sub-class value assigned, then the class value is the value used for RXDRGNAM.
In 1996-2013 samples, in the case that a prescription drug name was determined to be a confidentiality risk, RXDRGNAM is assigned a value of 8 Unknown-not ascertained.
Additionally, diabetic equipment and supplies (see RXNAME) are also assigned a RXDRGNAM value of 8 Unknown-not ascertained for all years.
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: MULTC1
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, except diabetic equipment and supplies (see RXNAME), MULTC1 is one of a set of variables that classifies drugs using the Multum Lexicon database therapeutic classification system (for more information, see the following section).
MULTC1 is on the prescribed medication-round fill record (or "medication-round fill record," see RECTYPE for more details on the different record types in IPUMS MEPS). Variables offered on the medication-round fill record through IPUMS MEPS are derived from the prescribed medicines file provided by AHRQ. Please see our overview of the event, medical conditions, and prescribed medicines variables, including how those variables are offered through IPUMS MEPS, and general considerations to keep in mind when conducting analyses using these variables.
IPUMS MEPS reports the universe for each variable based on a thorough review of the original MEPS documentation. Investigating the data may reveal cases that do not meet the stated universe. Users are encouraged to validate universes for their analyses. Additionally, users should proceed with caution when using the Multum Lexicon therapeutic class variables because the classification scheme has changed over time with the addition of new classes and sub-classes and changes to the hierarchy of classes. See the comparability tab for more details.
Multum Lexicon Variables
Cerner Multum, Inc. develops the Multum Lexicon database that MEPS uses to classify drugs reported by respondents in the MEPS-HC into the therapeutic class, sub-class, and sub-sub-class variables. In this classification system, each drug is assigned to a maximum of three therapeutic classes, such as cardiovascular agents or psychotherapeutic agents. Within each therapeutic class, drugs can also be assigned to one or more sub-classes, such as diuretics or antidepressants. Within each sub-class, drugs can also be assigned to one or more sub-sub-classes, such as loop diuretics or SSRI antidepressants. IPUMS MEPS currently offers the first therapeutic class a drug was assigned to as well as the corresponding sub-classes and sub-sub-classes. These variables include:
Multum Lexicon therapeutic class variables MULTC1: Multum Lexicon therapeutic class 1
MULTC1S1: Multum Lexicon therapeutic class 1, sub-class 1
MULTC1S1S1: Multum Lexicon therapeutic class 1, sub-class 1, sub-sub-class 1
MULTC1S1S2: Multum Lexicon therapeutic class 1, sub-class 1, sub-sub-class 2
MULTC1S2: Multum Lexicon therapeutic class 1, sub-class 2
MULTC1S2S1: Multum Lexicon therapeutic class 1, sub-class 2, sub-sub-class 1
MULTC1S3: Multum Lexicon therapeutic class 1, sub-class 3
MULTC1S3S1: Multum Lexicon therapeutic class 1, sub-class 3, sub-sub-class 1 IPUMS MEPS plans to release additional Multum Lexicon therapeutic class variables in the future.
Other Multum Lexicon variables available through IPUMS MEPS PREGCAT
RXDRGNAM Take note: IPUMS MEPS offers corrected Multum Lexicon data
Users should note that in 2017, AHRQ released Multum Lexicon Addendum files for 1996-2013 after discovering incorrect linkages between the MEPS Prescribed Medicines files and the Cerner Multum file, resulting in some incorrect therapeutic classes being assigned. The errors involved some diagnostic tests and medical devices that were accidentally assigned to a therapeutic class and should not have been. These errors included the following:
Some diabetic supplies erroneously assigned to a sex hormone sub-class in 1996-2002 and then erroneously assigned to a toxoids sub-class in 2003-2010.
The national drug code (NDC) 00169750111 was being misassigned. It should have been assigned to MULTC1=358 and MULTC1S1=99. The released addendum files contained corrected versions of the therapeutic class and sub-class variables and PREGCAT. They also contained RXDRGNAM, which was not previously released for 1996-2012. The 2013 Multum Lexicon Addendum file also contained corrected values of RXDRGNAM for some records.
IPUMS MEPS provides the corrected versions of the Multum Lexicon therapeutic class and sub-class variables as well as PREGCAT and RXDRGNAM for all years.
Users using the Multum Lexicon variables should cite Multum Lexicon, AHRQ, and IPUMS MEPS as the data sources.
var.codInstr:
CodesMULTC1 is a 3-digit numeric variable.
In all samples, diabetic equipment or supplies are assigned a MULTC1 value of 8: "Unknown Not Ascertained."
var.concept: Prescribed Medicine Fills Variables -- RX MEDICINES

var.name: MULTC1S1
var.txt:
For all medication-round fills, except diabetic equipment and supplies (see RXNAME), MULTC1S1 reports the first sub-class within the first class (MULTC1) a drug is assigned using the Multum Lexicon database therapeutic classification system.
MULTC1S1 is part of the Multum Lexicon database variable set. Cerner Multum, Inc. develops the Multum Lexicon database that MEPS uses to classify drugs reported by respondents in the MEPS-HC into the therapeutic class, sub-class, and sub-sub-class variables. In this classification system, each drug is assigned to a maximum of three therapeutic classes, such as cardiovascular agents or psychotherapeutic agents. Within each therapeutic class, drugs can also be assigned to one or more sub-classes, such as diuretics or antidepressants. Within each sub-class, drugs can also be assigned to one or more sub-sub-classes, such as loop diuretics or SSRI antidepressants. IPUMS MEPS currently offers the first therapeutic class (MULTC1) a drug was assigned to as well as the corresponding sub-classes and sub-sub-classes.
For related variables and more information about the Multum Lexicon database variable set, please see MULTC1.
